abstract: In a sign of shifting power, three bank titans said bad weather stopped them from meeting with the president.
snippet: In a sign of shifting power, three bank titans said bad weather stopped them from meeting with the president.
lead_paragraph: President Obama didn’t exactly look thrilled as he stared at the Polycom speakerphone in front of him. “Well, I appreciate you guys calling in,” he began the meeting at the White House with Wall Street’s top brass on Monday.

headline.main: Putting Obama on Hold, in a Hint of Who’s Boss
headline.print_headline: Putting Obama on Hold, In a Hint of Who’s Boss

abstract: When the taxpayers were the shareholders of major American banks, Washington had a say in how they were run. But now the White House has been left in the position of extending invitations, rather than exercising its clout.
snippet: When the taxpayers were the shareholders of major American banks, Washington had a say in how they were run. But now the White House has been left in the position of extending invitations, rather than exercising its clout.
lead_paragraph: Now that Citigroup has given back its bailout money — and Wells Fargo announced late on Monday that it would, too — whatever leverage Washington had over the financial services industry seems to be quickly eroding, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline.main: Putting Obama on Hold, in a Hint of Who’s Boss

abstract: Amid the ongoing parlor game of who will replace Kenneth D. Lewis as Bank of America’s next chief, Bloomberg News reported that the bank was most likely to tap someone from its own ranks for the job.
snippet: Amid the ongoing parlor game of who will replace Kenneth D. Lewis as Bank of America’s next chief, Bloomberg News reported that the bank was most likely to tap someone from its own ranks for the job.
lead_paragraph: In the ongoing parlor game of who will replace Kenneth D. Lewis as Bank of America‘s next chief, Bloomberg News reported that the bank is most likely to tap someone from its own ranks for the top job.

headline.main: Bank of America Said to Look Inside for C.E.O.
